Hi Aline,

Sounds like you've probably got bugs in your code... the best ge=
neric
answer I've got is to put in some debug statements to make sure the
d=
ifferent parts of your program are doing what you think they should be
doin=
g. E.g. is the selection process selecting correctly, is the speciation
cod=
e speciating correctly.

Cheers,
Oliver


T: 0421 972 953 | E: oliver.colem=
an@... | W: http://ojcoleman.com



On 25 July 2013 00:27, alinehuf2 =
<alinehuf2@...> wrote:

> **
>
>
> Hello all,
>
> I'm a french studen=
t at Paris university (sorry for my "broken" English).
> I'm doing my first=
 steps with NEAT and I encounter some difficulties. I
> have read the FAQ o=
n this web page :
> http://www.cs.ucf.edu/~kstanley/neat.html but I have no=
t found answers to
> my problems.
> I converted the Buckland implementation=
 from C++ to C (I am not
> comfortable with C++) : https://github.com/aline=
huf/neattest.
> I tried the XOR test as decribed by Stanley in "Evolving Ne=
ural Networks
> through Augmenting Topologies", but I had a really poor res=
ult. My program
> found a solution 981 times out of 1000 tests (98%) and it=
 tooks an average
> of 184 generations and a solution has 5 hidden nodes=85=

>
> I tried to change my implementation to make it look more like the
> St=
anley's neat 1.1 (reproduction and delta coding). In his article
> "Evolvin=
g Neural Networks through Augmenting Topologies" he said that NEAT
> can so=
lde the XOR problem 100% of the time, in an average of 32 generations
> and=
 2,35 hidden nodes=85 but even with the modifications the results of my
> p=
rogram are always disappointing (100% solution found in an average of 130
>=
 generation and with 5 hidden neurons)=85
>
> Buckland uses parameters quit=
e different from those of Stanley especially
> concerning the penalization =
or bonus awarded to the species :
> iYoungBonusAgeThreshhold =3D> 10
> dYou=
ngFitnessBonus =3D> Stanley 1.0 - Buckland 1.3
> iOldAgeThreshold =3D> Stan=
ley 15 - Buckland 50
> dOldAgePenalty =3D> Stanley 0.01 - Buckland 0.7
> I =
tested both sets of parameters without any significant difference in the
> =
average result for the 1000 tests.
>
> I tried different variations in repr=
oductive functions, speciation,
> mutation ... but without more success.
>
=
> When I look at my log file, I realize that the best species (or best
> ge=
nome) dies regularly. Sometimes the best species doesn't evolve for some
> =
generation and is fatally penalized. The best species doesn't reproduce and=

> then the best fitness disappears=85
>
> My goal is to use NEAT to evalua=
te the final positions of games in General
> Game Playing. If NEAT can pred=
ict the score, then I hope to be able to use
> the network generated to eva=
luate non-terminal positions. But for the
> moment, I do not manage to achi=
eve satisfactory results with the simple XOR
> problem and I do not know wh=
at could be the problem. Do you have any advice
> or tips?
>
> Best regards=
,
> Aline Huf.
>
>  
>

Sounds like you've probably got bugs in your code... the b=
est generic answer I've got is to put in some debug statements to make =
sure the different parts of your program are doing what you think they shou=
ld be doing. E.g. is the selection process selecting correctly, is the spec=
iation code speciating correctly.</div>

<br><br><div class=3D"gmail_quote">On 25 July 2013 00:27, aline=
huf2 <span dir=3D"ltr"><<a href=3D"mailto:alinehuf2@..." target=3D=
"_blank">alinehuf2@...</a>></span> wrote:<br><blockquote class=3D"=
gmail_quote" style=3D"margin:0 0 0 .8ex;border-left:1px #ccc solid;padding-=
left:1ex">



<u></u>










<div style>
<span>=A0</span>


<div>
  <div=
>


    <div>
      
      
      <p>Hello all,<br>
<br>
I'm a french s=
tudent at Paris university (sorry for my "broken" English).<br>
I=
'm doing my first steps with NEAT and I encounter some difficulties. I =
have read the FAQ on this web page : <a href=3D"http://www.cs.ucf.edu/~ksta=
nley/neat.html" target=3D"_blank">http://www.cs.ucf.edu/~kstanley/neat.html=
</a> but I have not found answers to my problems.<br>

I converted the Buck=
land implementation from C++ to C (I am not comfortable with C++) : <a href=
=3D"https://github.com/alinehuf/neattest." target=3D"_blank">https://github=
.com/alinehuf/neattest.</a> <br>
I tried the XOR test as decribed by Stanle=
y in "Evolving Neural Networks through Augmenting Topologies", bu=
t I had a really poor result. My program found a solution 981 times out of =
1000 tests (98%) and it tooks an average of 184 generations and a solution =
has 5 hidden nodes=85<br>

<br>
I tried to change my implementation to make=
 it look more like the Stanley's neat 1.1 (reproduction and delta codin=
g). In his article "Evolving Neural Networks through Augmenting Topolo=
gies" he said that NEAT can solde the XOR problem 100% of the time, in=
 an average of 32 generations and 2,35 hidden nodes=85 but even with the mo=
difications the results of my program are always disappointing (100% soluti=
on found in an average of 130 generation and with 5 hidden neurons)=85 <br>=


<br>
Buckland uses parameters quite different from those of Stanley espec=
ially concerning the penalization or bonus awarded to the species :<br>
iYo=
ungBonusAgeThreshhold =3D> 10<br>
dYoungFitnessBonus =3D> Stanley 1.0=
  - Buckland 1.3<br>
iOldAgeThreshold =3D> Stanley 15   - Buckland 50<br=
>
dOldAgePenalty =3D> Stanley 0.01 - Buckland 0.7<br>
I tested both sets=
 of parameters without any significant difference in the average result for=
 the 1000 tests.<br>
<br>
I tried different variations in reproductive func=
tions, speciation, mutation ... but without more success.<br>
<br>
When I l=
ook at my log file, I realize that the best species (or best genome) dies r=
egularly. Sometimes the best species doesn't evolve for some generation=
 and is fatally penalized. The best species doesn't reproduce and then =
the best fitness disappears=85<br>

<br>
My goal is to use NEAT to evaluate=
 the final positions of games in General Game Playing. If NEAT can predict =
the score, then I hope to be able to use the network generated to evaluate =
non-terminal positions. But for the moment, I do not manage to achieve sati=
sfactory results with the simple XOR problem and I do not know what could b=
e the problem. Do you have any advice or tips?<br>

<br>
Best regards,<br>
=
Aline Huf.<br>
<br>
</p>

    </div>
     

    
    <div style=3D"color:#f=
ff;min-height:0"></div>


</div>



  






</blockquote></div><br></div>
